post.author: bpanjavan
post.title: Silverlight - The Bare Minimum
post.content:
This post will demonstrate [how simple and easy it is to set up] the bare minimum needed to get a Silverlight 1.0 application up and running.

This post is NOT intended to:

  • Provide an introduction to XAML. Don’t worry if you don’t know what that is.
  • Provide an introduction to Silverlight. Ironic as it is, this shouldn’t be considered a “Silverlight: Lesson 1″ crash course. If I were going to teach my 15 year old to drive, I would start by talking about the car interface, NOT by putting her onto the road.
  • Provide an introduction to Silverlight development tools. Not every one of us has a Premium MSDN subscription. Every file used in this example can be edited using Notepad. Or better, Notepad2.

Software Requirements:

  • A way to set up a web-site (Like IIS 6 on a Windows Operating System). I know this sounds like a no-brainer, but in all seriousness, I’ve seen people create what they think is a Silverlight application when all they’ve done is open a XAML file with their browser.
  • Silverlight Runtime
  • Silverlight 1.0 SDK

Instructions:

1. Create your web site and directory. I don’t know how it’s done on a MAC, or with Apache on Unix, but here’s how it’s done in IIS 6 on Windows:

Open IIS Manager (START -> Control Panel -> Administrative Tools -> Internet Information (IIS) Manager). Then create a new web location by navigating under one of your existing web sites (ex. “Default Web Site”) and right clicking one of the web sites and choose “Virtual Directory”. I called mine “Silverlight_Minimum”. Set it to a folder of your choice. Check “Read”, “Run Scripts”, “Execute”, and “Browse”. Click “Finish”.

2. We need a default HTML page. On our default page we’ll create an element that will house our Silverlight Plugin. In this example I’m using a div entitled “mySilverlightPlugin”. Place this in our directory (the one you created in the last step).

Default.html

3. We need our XAML file. This file contains XAML code, the “bread and butter” of Silverlight. The material in this file will go inside the host div that I named “mySilverlightPlugin” in the previous step. Our XAML contains a simple text block element (YES, this is a “hello world” example).

Default.xaml

4. We need a JavaScript file to instantiate our Silverlight plug-in on our HTML page with our XAML file. Arguably the code in this file can go on the “Default.html” page itself, but for encapsulation purposes, I prefer to keep it in a a separate folder called “Scripts”. This example assumes the latter.

In this file you’ll notice the function to instantiate our Silverlight control. At the bottom there is some event handling logic going on to handle a user clicking on our text block.

CreateSilverlight.js

5. The final file we need is the “Silverlight.js” file. In a nutshell, this file is responsible for the magic that happens in order to instantiate our Silverlight control into our HTML page. You may have noticed, this file and the file in the previous step must be referenced by your HTML page. Place this file in the “Scripts” folder.

Distribution rights prohibit me from providing this file. Instead you must copy it from a directory where you installed your Silverlight 1.0 SDK.
Typically: Program Files\Microsoft Silverlight 1.0 SDK\Tools\Silverlight.js

Your directory should look like this:
Default.html
Default.xaml
Scripts\CreateSilverlight.js
Script\Silverlight.js

Finish!

That’s it. Now navigate to your site and click on the “Hello World” text block to test your application. The text should change to “Goodbye Cruel World!” when the text is clicked.

comment.content: 10 regular smokers were selected for the study. They were given a cycle each and asked to pedal at moderate speed, after they were abstained from nicotine intake for 15 hours. Then they were given FMRI (which refers to Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging) scans as they were shown 60 images. Among those pictures were some showing cigarettes to stimulate the craving in smokers. The next study was done on the same 10 people. They were given the same FMRI scan and the same photos were shown to them again. The brain images that were captured during both the studies show a substantial difference. In the second scan reports, patients display signs that indicated they craved for a smoke.

comment.author: &amp;#1511;&amp;#1493;&amp;#1512;&amp;#1505; &amp;#1489;&amp;#1513;&amp;#1493;&amp;#1511; &amp;#1492;&amp;#1492;&amp;#1493;&amp;#1503;
comment.content: Why does exercise reduce cigarette cravings? There are several reasons. First of all, the thought or activity of exercising will distract a person from wanting to light up. Another reason is that exercise relaxes our body and muscles, and reduces stress. Since a lot of people smoke to relieve stress, it is hypothesized that exercise fulfills that goal and so a person has less reason to want a cigarette. It is thought that working out uplifts your mood as dopamine levels are increased, and so there is less incremental pleasure from smoking after exercising.

comment.author: &amp;#1502;&amp;#1499;&amp;#1500;&amp;#1500;&amp;#1514; &amp;#1508;&amp;#1505;&amp;#1490;&amp;#1493;&amp;#1514;
comment.content: All in all, it appears that light to moderate exercising can help one quit smoking. A walk or jog in the park is free compared to buying patches or other smoke cessation aids. In addition, exercise benefits your general heath as well. Given all these advantages, this seems like a good method to use if you are serious about quitting.
